documents.title: this is it for today !
text: thanks everyone for your questions , and to kevin for his brilliant answers and for going the extra mile to answer as many as he could .
until next time !
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:12pm thanks for the questions - some great ones , really interesting , and sorry if i could n't answer yours .
but i 'm starving and i can see a wagamama 's from here .
i 'm hungry after talking about clarkies helicopters .
and thanks to anyone who came to see the shows this year , much appreciated .
vammyp asks : have you ever drunk so much buckfast you looked in the mirror to see jason manford ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:10pm nah .
i was in plymouth last week , and someone told me they brew it down there , but no-one drinks it down there , they just sent it to scotland for us to stab each other over a football game .
me and jason used to play pro evo actually .
atticus finch asks : do you think scottish comedy is promoted in the uk in general .
i 'm talking specifically about still game here .
it 's the funniest sit-com to be commissioned by the bbc in years , but hardly anyone in england has seen it .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:08pm in my opinion , i think it 's brilliant , but you ca n't force it on everyone .
when i first started in comedy , all my gigs were in scotland , but when i first started coming to london , i did these jokes about scotland - i was told to broaden my mind a bit .
i was developing a following in scotland , but hammering london too , and it forced me to be broad .
still game is n't scottish comedy , i see it as an accessible sitcom about old people and their lives .
maybe it 's working class comedy , these guys in the pub with their whisky .
kungpowwow asks : albert einstein or nikola tesla ?
who is the greatest ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:06pm albert einstein .
tesla 's got a girl 's name , whereas albert is the polar opposite .
alastair m hart asks : hello kevin , i was at hammersmith on the thursday night ( current tour ) .
how do you yourself up after a bunch of eejits try to spoil your show ?
ps .
you were excellent .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:06pm it 's frustrating , man .
you 're trying to put on a great show , and you go to clubs , working up material , trying to give people something different .
and people heckle with your own old jokes .
it 's boring , and boring for other people .
you kind of feel for them .
it must be annoying sitting next to them .
how you yourself up is that it 's only a few people - lots of people are actually laughing and enjoying it and loving it .
in london gigs , scottish people come down and treat it like euro 96 - people shouting : i 'm from motherwell !
you can feel the booze in the room , and it 's going to put people off me , because it 's the hooligan element of your fanbase .
and you think : would people accept it if i just did selfies with people and did old material ?
hopefully not .
it 's a minority , but a very audible one .
maybe they 'll see what standup is , and the next tour , they 'll get that it 's not about seeing someone off the telly .
petergriffin asks : have you every thought of doing something else bar standup ?
frankie boyle for example has dabbled in media commentary and comic books , so is there anything you fancy doing ?
and oh , less of the lip towards the mighty thistle ! !
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:02pm aye , i would love to do a travel show , and to write something .
i always have ideas , but whenever i see something funny , i think of it as standup .
so it would be interesting to write up my notes as a funny short film , or a scripted comedy .
i enjoyed writing my book as well , i used to write short stories for my own entertainment .
frankie does great stuff for the guardian , his articles are brilliant .
a podcast would be good too , get some interesting people on .
graham hunter does a great one that i guested on .
sammyvy asks : what is the worst heckle you have had and how did you respond ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:57pm someone threatened to kick my cunt in .
even in scotland , that 's aggressive .
i do n't even have a cunt .
he was prepared to perform an immediate sex change on me , then undo his own gynecological efforts with his own foot .
grimble44 asks : any advice for those in edinburgh cut off from civilisation by the closure of the forth bridge kevin ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 2:00pm nothing to worry about from not getting to fife .
keep the fifers in fife .
it 's a good thing for the whole of scotland .
theshiftyshadow asks : do you prefer building sandcastles or snowmen ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:59pm sandcastles , because it implies you 're on holiday .
i 've never built one either .
it 's a bit more complex a sandcastle though a snowman you can have a bit of a laugh with the immature stuff , making a phallus from a carrot .
so a snowman .
good question !
dannyh1990 asks : what 's your favourite episode of the sopranos ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:55pm i just watched a clip of christopher 's intervention - it 's worth it for silvio alone .
he just tells him that his hair was in the toilet water and it 's disgusting the russian in the woods , i know everyone says that 's their favourite but it is great .
when they 're fighting over the ketchup .
you see the real paulie , and realise he 's a bit of a shitebag .
glen pierce asks : tizer or irn bru ?
oor wullie or the broons ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:52pm irn bru and the broons .
ritchiepk asks : what are your top five flavours of crisps of all time ?

for example mine are scampi fries pickled onion monster munch ( circa 1985 before they removed the carcinogens ) golden wonder salt and vinegar football crazy 's and top of the shop has to be smith 's bovril flavour .
sadly long gone !
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:52pm brannigans went underground : roast beef and mustard with a cold pint of tennents .
worcester sauce too .
they need to get back in the game !
i like mackies too , they 're a new crisp - i think they 're in tesco .
a nice cut - but not too clean cut like a pringle , which is unnatural .
it 's too presentable .
mackies are shapely , but not unerringly so .
aberdeen angus flavour .
and crispy bacon ghosties - i 've used it in an edible and toilet-based format here today .
and meanies , onion flavour .
10p crisps , you do n't have to commit to one packet - you can build up a selection .
smudger1 asks : have you been offered any acting roles yet ?
and is that something you would consider ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:49pm have been offered some stuff .

the first is quite a serious part , and that 's a bit of a test of my untested acting abilities after this tour it would maybe be good to submerge myself in something good and outside my comfort zone though .
i find it hard to read scripts - you can never tell if it 's going to be good .
but when you meet people you can gauge if it 's going to be good .
the character i 've been offered is a bad man it 's quite dark .
i 've looking at a couple of things actually .
with standup you 've got total control , so saying someone else 's lines , that puts me off a little .
bongiben asks : how 's dunn 's doing , any updates ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:47pm it 's a clothes shop - i said it was somewhere between primark and shoplifting .
robdavy asks : now you are famous will you be cushtying up with the royals ?
you know , just like that other hypocrite , the big yin .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:46pm a bit harsh , calling the big yin a hypocrite , and calling me one too .
you ca n't call him an affectionate nickname !
i do n't have an opinion on the royals - it 's just a bit uncool is n't it , to do the royal variety performance , and i 've been asked .
i just do n't recognise them as being anything - nothing against them though .
robdavy asks : if you were the leader of a moist cult would you still wash the dishes ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:44pm i would love to be the leader of a moist cult .
i would even do the dishwashing .
jrio asks : i 'd like to know what your favourite bridge is .
if you do n't have one , who is your favourite bridges : lloyd , jeff or beau .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:43pm nash .
i tried to create my own nickname at school , and tried to put the word out there that people were calling me nash .

andbaconstrips asks : yeah your thoughts please kevin on the prospect of the euro reaching parity with the dollar sometime next year , as some analysts are currently predicting , and how this development might impact upon montenegro 's ability to continue attracting fdi in the increasingly competitive biotech sector ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:43pm i had a feeling this might pop up .
right now , i do n't feel i should comment on the situation .
let 's sit back and watch how it develops .
brumdog asks : what are the best and worst parts about your job ?
and did you get any tickets for the euros ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:42pm probably the solitude , and that 's the answer to both .
when a gig has gone well , it 's all on you - and when it goes bad , all the blame is on you too .
the waiting i find hard - seven hours til you 're on stage , it 's always on your mind .
i might start doing them at 9am so they 're out of the way .
there 's too much thinking to be done .
your day relies on the reaction of other people , and that 's why we standups are generally such needy , fucked-up people .
elpoppa asks : what 's you favorite city to gig in ?
also , you still a pro evo man ?
or have you been seduced by the dark side ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:40pm it 's quite a tempermental question , because it changes , but this year i thoroughly enjoyed dublin .
glasgow is always good as well , of course .
there 's pressure in glasgow though - if you die on your arse , you have to see them the next day .
i really enjoyed oslo and trondheim this year - amazing crowds , and standup 's quite new to them .
their english is fucking incredible , they understand puns and wordplay .
newcastle too is great .
and you 'll go to southampton or cheltenham and they 're surprisingly great too .
jack grimes asks : is there a better roll than a helicopter from clarkies , and if so , where is it ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:38pm no .
i can state quite categorically there is n't .
this is a 24 hour bakery in dundee , and i recommended the helicopter to adam richman of man vs food .
i was trying to drag him up to scotland .
it 's got links sausage , square sausage , bacon , hamburger , black pudding and a fried egg and some chips .
it 's hard to resist - we were there every night after the tour there this year .
they have 15 kinds of pies , cakes , chips it 's in a retail park so it 's hard to find , but when you see greggs in dundee you 're like , why ? ?
you 've got clarkies man !
tuppery asks : kevin , if you could ask david cameron any question on live tv , what would it be ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:36pm i would look him in the eye and say : what 's your fuckin ' problem mate ?
then i would throw a punch just to make him flinch , in a really pathetic way .
he 's got a highly slappable face .
he needs a slap rather than a punch .
mm65 asks : do you think scotland has changed since the referendum ?
were you good at solo talk at school ?
( i 'm an english teacher and i love a wean who does funny solo talks . )
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:32pm i 've been on the road since the referendum mostly , but aye , everyone 's politically educated now .
it was a good time - people felt their vote would matter .
people were a bit down about it , because it 's back to the same old shit - 57 mps out of 59 voted against the syrian airstrikes .
people feel a bit despondent , and i do n't think there 'll be a second referendum - people need to move on .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:35pm we 're kind of stuck in a bad place - i do n't really know what happens next .
solo talk i was always in trouble for carrying on at school , and i would get frustrated .

i would end up in the exclusion room , doing my work on my own , and i 'd seen the shawshank redemption - i did an essay about the exclusion room , and did it like a prison journal , and wrote about the inhumane conditions , and my plan for when i got released .
i could stand up and be funny .
so i was quite good at solo talk .
kazoom asks : the bloke 's voice at my local tesco 's self-service checkout : is that you doing your english accent or is it he who you learnt it from ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:30pm if he ever steps down , i 'll offer my services to tesco .

maybe that 's where i learned that voice guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:30pm tesco need to bring out a rosetta stone type deal , teaching people english accents from their bagging areas .
nigel fox asks : has kevin met henrik larson since he got marker pen ink on his jeans ?
has kevin met hugh grant and apologised to him for stealing his cardboard cut-out from the cinema in glasgow ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:29pm no !
that 's a true story .
getting tickets at celtic park , we went running up , and it was the 90s - you never had a mobile phone for a selfie .
someone was getting an autograph , and all i had was my bus ticket - he leaned on his light blue jeans , and the pen went through the ticket onto his jeans .
to me it was awful , i 'd ruined his outfit .
and then it was covering the date , so the bus driver was saying it did n't count he was a rangers fan .
i thought it should be valid for a month with larsson 's autograph .
i 've never met him since though .
i told that story on this morning and he sent them a signed for me .
stacy cain asks : what was it like meeting the legend that is noel gallagher ? !
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:27pm they say never meet your heroes , but he 's exactly how you 'd imagine - hilarious , a genuinely funny guy .
a cool dude - you 're just instantly relaxed , because he 's so genuine .
there 's something infectious about someone who 's that comfortable with themselves .
we tried to meet up the other week for a quick pint , but he was heading to bono 's for tea and toast - which was a pretty incredible text to receive .
he had a fridge full of tennent 's lager at his hydro gig , and i was off booze for 51 weeks , so could n't have one without doing the full year he dedicated digsby 's dinner to me .
i then got back on it at the royal albert hall with him a few weeks later .
he had his ipad out and was like what do you want to listen to ?
i was like rock n roll star !
talk tonight !
the first time he got in touch he was running the teenage cancer trust gigs , and he called me up out of the blue , and said kevin , it 's noel , roger daltry gave me your number .
i wanted to have that recorded to play to anyone who ever doubted me .
mark davidson asks : should boaby be in the dictionary ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:23pm i 'm laughing at the guardian trying to pronounce this .
boaby means cock .
people say `` the boaby '' , as in `` she likes the boaby '' .
`` the boaby '' should be in the dictionary .
i think it 's in dictionaries in my old school in black marker pen .
`` mrs henderson likes the boaby . ''
ambrosethegentleman asks : was the horth story actually true ?
finest panel show appearance by anyone ever .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:21pm it was on would i lie to you - that i bought a horse in bulgaria .
accidentally .
and yes it 's true - i was on holiday with my mate and his mum and dad , and we were pretty bored .
we were on the beach and we were approached about horse riding - there was only one horse .
the guy took our money , and we thought he was off to get another horse for us , but he never returned .
we had to phone our mate 's dad , and he got someone to phone the bulgarian animal rights .
i wanted to keep it but it would n't fit in the `` does your bag fit in this '' holder at the airport '' .
breeno67 asks : kev i n favourite ground to watch fitbaw at in scotland other than paradise or ibrokes ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:19pm paradise is always good - it 's got a really low roof at one end .

scottish football , because it 's pretty awful at the moment , should have `` a good day oot '' rule - dundee should start with 30 points because they 're a good day out , but teams like hamilton , partick thistle , they should start with minus 30 because it 's a shit day out .
maybe that 's a celtic fan talking .
tynecastle 's a good stadium , always a good atmosphere .
always a heated affair , celtic vs hearts .
definitely need the good day oot rule though .
note : kevin actually said tannadice , not paradise , in his answer to this question our apologies for the transcription error .
christopher clark asks : i was at your edinburgh playhouse gig and loved it but i was appalled by the lack of respect that some of the audience gave you and your warm up act .
is this now seen in the comedy circuit as just the way it is now or is there any solutions to the constant heckles and people leaving and coming back ?
cheers lad .
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:16pm that just comes with popularity .
this year someone said i played to half a million people , so if 1 % are arseholes , that 's like five thousand arseholes .
it 's people who have never been to standup before , and it 's crossed into celebrity and pop culture , and people see you as somebody famous .
it 's mindblowing shit - i was halfway through a joke , someone said my uncle was your driving instructor .
maybe you do n't do as many shows , or sell just on your website it 's people who 'll just go onto the next person next year .
i do n't believe i 'll ever be as popular as i 'll be this year .
and that 's fine - i do n't particularly enjoy when the crowd 's a bit t in the park .
there was a guy in the front row with a copy of my book - and i signed his book .
then someone walks up wanting a selfie , and fair enough , but then a grown guy wants another one - i say right , let 's do it , and he wanted it on stage .
i was like mate : fuck off .
he told me i 'd forgotten my roots .
the crowd clapped for me , but the next day it 's in the record `` heated exchange with fan '' .
comedy needs context .
it 's hard though because it 's friendly most of the time .
readabout21 asks : what , if anything , would you not consider a topic for a stage comedy act ?
( ps .
you are great at what you do thanks for the laughs ) guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:10pm see the above question .
belly button fluff .
people keep it in a jar ?
that 's horrible .
i think i 've seen people 's collections in magazines .
lint - even that word is horrible .
i always try and wash inside the belly button see , i would not consider that a topic for a stage comedy act .
you can talk about anything as long as it 's funny , but toilet humour can divide the crowd unless it 's done well .
i had quite a nice routine in my last show , about having a ghostie but as long as it 's not focused on the faeces itself .
as long as it comes from a place where you 're trying to be funny , and as long as you 're comfortable .
i would never set certain subjects , and think : how can i make this funny ?
the joke comes first .
there 's nothing worse than watching someone who thinks they 're being edgy or dangerous .
frankie boyle 's stuff , i find him funny , it 's well written - it just happens to be what some people find offensive , and that 's their problem .
tony doyle asks : what was your best moment watching celtic ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:06pm really difficult to pin this down .
been thinking about it a lot recently , because it 's a grim transitional period at the moment .
may 9 , 1998 , the first time i saw them win in the league - we stopped rangers winning a tenth league title in a row .
saw them at home to st johnstone .
i felt extra smug - turned up at the end of nine years of shit .
henrik larsson and harold brattbakk , whose now a pilot in norway .
a roasting hot day , a full scale pitch invasion , all these people outside the stadium came running in .
lou reed 's perfect day played , and everyone sang .
also the uefa cup in seville in 2003 , which put me on the path to comedy - because i had missed two exams to go to the match under my own dad 's advice , and very much against my mum 's advice .
it led me to getting chucked out of school , and at a loose end , and reading frank skinner 's book one day , and thinking it could be a solution .
jose mourinho , it was his first european cup , and it was a classic mourinho team - loads of diving .
i 've since brought him up on it when i met him at soccer aid .
frankiebhoy93 asks : hi kevin , i am a big admirer of your work .
what are your favourite british and american sitcoms ?
guardian contributor kevinbridges 07 december 2015 1:02pm only fools and horses is timeless - even though it 's so old , it 's the only thing that makes me settled , when it 's on uk gold .
bottom as well - reminds me of me and my dad sitting up on friday nights , and thinking how mental it is .
legit too - it 's excellent .
and louie - i do n't know if you could call it a sitcom .
i do n't even laugh , i just smile through it , it draws you in .
and curb your enthusiasm too - i 've just got into it recently .
everyone keeps recommending always sunny but i 'm trying to avoid it and be cool .
and find a foreign subtitled sitcom .
but i tend to watch serious stuff as an escape from comedy .
i just finished narcos which was great - and started game of thrones last night because my brother keeps hounding me to watch it .
intentional pun - i 've met the hound , nice guy .
and gomorrah , i thought that was excellent .
the movie was terrible , so boring , but the series is great .
peaky blinders - modern british comedians are so keen to hold up american comedians , so i need to big up something british .
it 's just as good as hbo .

documents.title: post your questions for kevin bridges
text: kevin bridges has one of the most instantly recognisable voices in standup and has firmly grasped the holy grail of comedy : being totally populist without resorting to cheap or easy gags .
as brian logan wrote of his current uk tour , he delivers mainstream comedy , but with very sharp elbows .
he skewers the pretensions of the middle classes often in an immaculate posh-liberal accent but also targets his own occasional ridiculousness , like his bemusement at gym bunnies .
he 's yet to turn 30 but has already released three live dvds , made numerous tv appearances including his own series and graduated to arena-filling status .

he 's currently on the road with his a whole different story tour which is also out now in dvd form and we 're catching up with him in sheffield on monday 7 december for a live webchat , at 1pm gmt onwards .
post your questions for him in the comments below , and he 'll take on as many as possible .
